frameDefinitions: This frame is about the static comparison of an Profiled_item to a Standard_item, often  with respect to some Attribute.
In this frame, an Entity or Behavior is suspicious or otherwise subject to question.
An Entity is rated as unexpected for its context in terms of its magnitude.
An Agent or Entity becomes sufficient enough to meet a Standard.
Words in this frame have to do with a Cognizer believing that some Phenomenon will take place in the future.
Compared to its Competitors, a Standard is at the high end of a scale with respect to some Variable.
frameExamples: The Sun is putting on a show that <t>rivals</t> the most sizzling Hollywood thrillers.
We found some <t>suspicious</t> checks lying on his desk.
The <t>entire</t> apple was riddled with worms .
This paper does not <t>meet</t> the requirements for graduation.
The taxpayer is supporting a system <t>unmatched</t> in wastefulness .
listRoleDefinitions: In active sentences, the <fen>Profiled_item</fen> is the grammatically more prominent one of the items that are compared and realized as  the subject. .
In active setnnces, the <fen>Standard_item</fen> is  the grammatically less prominent element, i.e. the object or an oblique.
This Frame Elements marks constituents that indicate in which respect Item-1 and Item-2 are equal to each other.
The <fen>Standard_attribute</fen> is used when the standard is a specific value on  a scale.
The <fen>Profiled_attribute</fen> is a particular value on a scale which is being compared to a <fen>Standard_item</fen> or <fen>Profiled_attribute</fen>.
The time at which the <fen>Profiled_item</fen> rivals the <fen>Standard_item</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Profiled_item</fen> rivals the <fen>Standard_item</fen>.
The <fen>Behavior</fen> is the state of affairs or action of the social actor that is regarded as susipcious.
An individual that is suspected of wrongdoing because of the <fen>Behavior</fen>.
The <fen>Entity</fen> metonymically stands in for a <fen>Behavior</fen> that saliently involves the <fen>Entity</fen>.
The item which is described in terms of its expectedness in the context.
The intentional <fen>Agent</fen> acts to meet to a <fen>Standard</fen>.
The non-intentional <fen>Entity</fen> becomes sufficient enough to meet a <fen>Standard</fen>.
An act or occurence that changes circumstances sufficiently so as to meet a <fen>Standard</fen>.
A condition or requirement that the <fen>Agent</fen>, <fen>Entity</fen>, or <fen>Event</fen> attempt to meet.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen>, <fen>Entity</fen>, or <fen>Event</fen> becomes sufficient in regards to the <fen>Standard</fen>.

This is the person who believes some Phenomenon will take place in the future. It is normally expressed as an External Argument: <fex name='Cognizer'>Pat</fex> <t>expects</t> that the Yankees will win the World Series.

This is what the Cognizer believes will happen in the future. It can be expressed as a Finite Clause Complement, an NP Object, or a VP Complement with or without an NP Object (see General Grammatical Observations):
An entity that serves as the focus of a predicted <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> makes the prediction.
The location where the <fen>Cognizer</fen> foresees the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The <fen>Standard</fen> is the entity that is located closest to the end of the scale evoked by some <fen>Variable</fen>.
The <fen>Variable</fen> is a property that evokes a scale along which the <fen>Standard</fen> is located closest to one extreme in  comparison to its <fen>Competitors</fen>.
The role <fen>Competitors</fen> denotes the entities that are exceeded by the <fen>Standard</fen> with regard to the <fen>Variable</fen>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>This PC</fex> stacks up well against its competitors
This PC stacks up well <fex>against its competitors</fex>
The Tri-Cities stack up well against the competition <fex>in the area of innovation</fex>
American caviar <fex>now</fex> rivals Russia's in quality.
<fex>In Africa</fex>, the level of drug resistance rivals even Noatirtin's vaunted efficacy.
The entire <fex>day</fex> was spent on the project .
Pat expects <fex>that the Yankees will win the World Series</fex>.
Predictions <fex>about stock prices</fex> are notoriously undependable.
She predicted the outcry <fex>several months ago</fex>.
<fex>Even at the far side of the house</fex> I could predict what was going on the kitchen.
<fex>Hilary</fex> was unmatched by any politician in the country.
Hilary was unmatched <fex>by any politician in the country</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: The De Villiers Coat of Arms
The University of the Cape of Good Hope
de Villiers Family – Volume I – Malherbe/Malan
the Dictionary of South African Biography
the second half of the 12th century
July to November 1912 and July to September 1914
